concept.title: Samples
concept.shortdesc: Samples, as distinct from examples, show what the completed results of a user's high-level task might look like, as opposed to just a fragment of a result.

conbody.p: For programming products, a sample is an executable piece of code that users can run with very little effort. The source code for the sample should make liberal use of comments that point out details that users should notice. Highlight key functions; for example, show off features that differentiate the IBM WebSphere Studio Workbench from Microsoft Visual InterDev. Ensure that the names of code variables are self-explanatory. For example, phone_number is easier to understand than pn. In addition to the sample itself, you should provide a topic that describes the sample and tells users how to run it. Sometimes, you can also include a tutorial that explains how to recreate a sample.

Even though samples may contain instructions on how to run them, they are not in fact tasks. The instructions on running are not the defining feature of the sample, they merely tell the user how to explore the sample. Typically you would document samples using the generic topic DTD, since more specific information types don't apply.

Samples documentation may consist of:
A description of the sample, with directions for where to find it.
A description of the sample, with directions for both finding and running it.
A complete code listing or equivalent, which the user can cut and paste to use directly. When the sample has a matching tutorial, the sample's documentation should include a link to the tutorial on output. (The link may be added by processing a map that ties samples and tutorials together with a relationship table.)
Typically, titles of topics that describe samples should start with the word "Sample". For example, "Sample: mailquery", or "Sample: User-defined methods".
